newsitem.title: USA: CFTC report indicated rough times for gasoline.
newsitem.headline: CFTC report indicated rough times for gasoline.

text.p: The CFTC Futures Commitment of Traders Report last week foreshadowed a decline in gasoline prices and next week's report will likely reflect the bearish turn by showing a decline in gasoline open interest.

"There was a lot of speculative length in gasoline, so I have to think gasoline was looking vulnerable to profit-taking, which was what we have seen," said John Saucer, analyst with Smith Barney in Houston.

For the two weeks ended March 25, long positions held by non-commercial traders had increased by 3,497 contracts to 14,097. Open interest for gasoline, the amount of long or short positions at the end of a trading session, stood at 99,180, particularly high for the unleaded contract.
Speculators had bought gasoline expecting the spot contract was poised to begin its traditional spring rally in anticipation of the summer driving season.
Since March 25, spot gasoline has fallen 3.85 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

"I think in the next report we are going to see that a lot of that (open interest) has disappeared, that there are not many new long or shorts that have entered gasoline," said Tom Bentz, analyst with ING Derivatives in New York.
Gasoline was vulnerable to profit-taking by jittery traders when crude prices continued to slide on ample supply, analysts said.

Commercial players such as refiners had increased their short positions in crude by 12,236 contracts to 262,845 contracts. The wisdom of these large players, typically described as the "smart money," panned out. Since March 25, spot crude has fallen 71 cents a barrel.

Speculative short positions in heating oil showed a sharp decrease, a move deemed fairly typical as heating oil's price firms this time of year as refiners shift away from distillate output to focus on gasoline production.
